summary: since the first case report in Saudi Arabia, MERS has been reported in more than 20 countries. the mortality of MERS is 4-fold higher than SARS (40% compared with 10%) the genome contains 16 NSPs except for 3CLpro and PLpro (18, 19) most of the functional domains within the NSP3 remain structurally uncharacterized. the macro domain is named after the non-histone motif of the histone variant macroH2A. poly(ADP)-ribosylation is a post-translational modification linked with DNA repair, apoptosis, gene regulation, and protein degradation. macro domain-containing proteins and enzymes may play important roles in regulating various cellular processes. some viral macro domains were found to have ADP-ribose 1′′-phosphate phosphatase (ADRP) activity (31–33) the macro domain of SARS-CoV NSP3 was previously reported to possess ADP-ribose and poly(ADP)-ribose binding ability. the macro domain may regulate cellular proteins involved in an apoptotic pathway via poly(ADP)-ribosylation to mediate the host response to infection. plasmid was transformed into Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) cells. cells were grown at 37 °C up to A600 1.0 with 50 g/ml of kanamycin. cell extract was clarified by centrifugation at 18,900 g for 30 min at 4 °C. a 25-l mixture containing 2 l of SYPRO Orange (Sigma), 1.25 l of dialysis buffer (20 mm Tris-HCl, and 100 mm NaCl, pH 7.0), 10 l of 1 m protein sample were mixed on ice in an 8-well PCR tube. the main measurements were carried out in triplicate. ITC titrated Aliquots of 3 l of 1.14 mm ADP-ribose by injection into protein (0.057 mm in 0.98 ml) in 20 mm Tris-HCl and 100 mm NaCl. heat from ligand to buffer titrations was subtracted. the crystal was soaked for 8 h in 3 mm mercuric(II) chloride, cryoprotected in mother liquor supplemented with 20% glycerol, and flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen at 100 K. the diffraction images were recorded in a 100-K nitrogen gas stream with use of BL13B1 or BL13C1 beamlines (National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taiwan) 47 1.00545 Resolution range (26.51–1.73 (1.79–1.73) 22.53–1.43 (1.48–1.43) 25 °C with 250 rpm stirring. the corrected heat from the binding reaction was used to derive values for the stoichiometry of the binding (n), Kd, apparent enthalpy of binding (H) and entropy change (S). the initial model was refined by the maximum likelihood method implemented in REFMAC5 (46) and rebuilt interactively by inspecting the -weighted electron density maps with coefficients 2mFo DFc and mFo DFc in COOT (48). During the later stages, restrained positional and B-factor refinement involved the program phenix.refine (49). redundancya 13.1 (12.6) 5.8 (5.8) CC1/2a,c 0.989 (0.953) 0.993 (0.972) CCanod 0.63 Anomalous redundancya 6.9 (6.6) Anomalous completenessa 98.9 (98.6) Refinement statistics Resolution () 1.43 Rwork (%)/Rfree (%)e 12.73 / 16.19 R.m.s. deviation Bonds (°) 1.213 Mean B-factor (2) CD spectra revealed that the macro domain exhibited a stable /-type folding pattern under various pH conditions. the Tm of the macro domain from thermal transition monitored by CD was 43 °C. however, the addition of ADP-ribose significantly increased the Tm to 51 °C. heat release on injection of 1.14 mm ADP-ribose into a cell containing 0.057 mm MERS-CoV macro domain. both DSF and ITC measurements were used to examine the equilibrium dissociation constant (Kd) of ADP-ribose. our Kd of 2.95 m from biochemical analysis suggests that the MERS-CoV macro domain interacts with ADP-ribose, which suggests further investigating the role of the macro domain in MERS-CoV infection. the core of the structure of MERS-CoV macro domain is a seven-stranded -sheet in the order of 1-2-7-6-3-5-4. the central -sheet is sandwiched between six -helices, with 1, 2, and 3 packing onto one face and 4, 5, and 6 onto the other. in the initial refinement cycle, a strong bent electron density was unambiguously identified as an ADP-ribose molecule. top-ranked structures were macro domains of coVs in complex with ADP-ribose. HCoV-229E (PDB code 3EWR; Z score 22.8; r.m.s. deviation 1.8; sequence identity 33%; sequence similarity 56%) (43), and infectious bronchitis virus (PDB code 3EWP; Z score 19.5; r.m.s. deviation 1.9; sequence identity 28%; sequence similarity 47%) (43 this residue is critical for binding specificity of the macro domain AF1521 in A. fulgidus (54) Oxygen atoms of the pyrophosphate in ADP-ribose contact surrounding residues via hydrogen bonding with nitrogen atoms. the second ribose is stabilized by complex hydrogen bonding with surrounding residues and water molecules. a close-up of interactions in MERS-CoV macro domain with ADP-ribose binding. amino acids and ADP-ribose are shown as sticks with carbon in marine blue and yellow, respectively. water molecules are shown as green spheres. interactions between MERS-CoV macro domain and ADP-ribose. secondary structures of MERS-CoV macro domain are depicted on the top of the alignment with arrows for strands and cylinders for helices. consensus amino acids among macro domains in CoVs with similarity score >0.7 are framed in yellow and depicted at the bottom of the alignment. structural divergence lies in the 1 helices, which participates in stabilization of ADP-ribose. in the MERS-CoV macro domain, the side chain of Asp-20 contacting ADP-ribose points into the cavity that holds adenine moiety. hydrogen bonding with Val-25 and Lys-26 of Asp-23 causes variation in side chain orientation from that for Asp-20 in the MERS-CoV macro domain. in the SARS-CoV macro domain, the lengths of hydrogen bonds formed by the Asp-20 side chain with Ile-22 and ADP-ribose are 2.96 and 2.82. differences in the context of hydrogen bonds formed by the conserved Asp with ADP-ribose may result in differential binding affinities for ADP-ribose. the relationship between binding affinities of ADP-ribose in macro domains and differential pathogenicity of human CoVs needs further investigation. the macro domain exhibited a stable /-type folding pattern. however, the addition of ADP-ribose significantly increased the Tm. the significant increase in Tm suggests the interaction between the MERS-CoV macro domain and ADP-ribose. mm ADP-ribose into a 980-l cell containing 0.057 mm MERS-CoV macro domain. both DSF and ITC measurements were used to examine the equilibrium dissociation constant (Kd) of ADP-ribose. m from biochemical analysis suggests that the MERS-CoV macro domain interacts with ADP-ribose. this suggests further investigating the role of the macro domain in infection. the core of the structure of MERS-CoV macro domain is a seven-stranded -sheet in the order of 1-2-7-6-3-5-4. the central -sheet is sandwiched between six -helices, with 1, 2, and 3 packing onto one face and 4, 5, and 6 onto the other. in the initial refinement cycle, a strong bent electron density (continuous at 1 cutoff) located at the central pocket, was unambiguously identified as an ADP-ribose top-ranked structures were macro domains of coVs in complex with ADP-ribose. HCoV-229E (PDB code 3EWR; Z score 22.8; r.m.s. deviation 1.8; sequence identity 33%; sequence similarity 56%) (43), and infectious bronchitis virus (PDB code 3EWP; Z score 19.5; r.m.s. deviation 1.9; sequence identity 28%; sequence similarity 47%) (43 structure-based multiple sequence alignment showed that this aspartic acid is conserved among coV macro domains. Oxygen atoms of the pyrophosphate in ADP-ribose contact surrounding residues via hydrogen bonding with nitrogen atoms. the second ribose is stabilized by complex hydrogen bonding with surrounding residues and water molecules. a close-up of interactions in MERS-CoV macro domain with ADP-ribose binding. amino acids and ADP-ribose are shown as sticks with carbon in marine blue and yellow, respectively; oxygen in red; nitrogen in blue; and phosphorus in orange. secondary structures of MERS-CoV macro domain are depicted on the top of the alignment with arrows for strands and cylinders for helices. consensus amino acids among macro domains in CoVs with similarity score >0.7 are framed in yellow and depicted at the bottom of the alignment. blue and green arrowheads on the top indicate equivalent amino acids in SARS-CoV macro domain found to abolish or decrease ADRP enzymatic activities when mutated domains in MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and HCoV-229E have been determined. major structural divergence lies in the 1 helices, which participates in stabilization of ADP-ribose. in the MERS-CoV macro domain, the side chain of Asp-20 contacting ADP-ribose points into the cavity that holds adenine moiety. the lengths of hydrogen bonds formed by the Asp-20 side chain with Ile-22 and ADP-ribose are 2.96 and 2.82, respectively. in the SARS-CoV macro domain, the lengths of hydrogen bonds formed by the Asp-20 side chain with Val-25 and ADP-ribose are 3.04 and 2.87. ose binding to the HCoV-229E macro domain suggests less contribution of the hydrogen bond to stabilization of ADP-ribose (41). differences in strength of the hydrogen bond and orientation of the side chain may result in differential binding affinities of ADP-ribose in macro domains. the Tm of the macro domain from thermal transition monitored by CD was 43 °C. however, the addition of ADP-ribose significantly increased the Tm to 51 °C. the significant increase in Tm suggests the interaction between the MERS-CoV macro domain and ADP-ribose. 980-l cell containing 0.057 mm MERS-CoV macro domain. compared with the Kd of ADP-ribose binding to macro domains of human CoVs. ERS-CoV macro domain possesses poly(ADP)-ribose binding ability. the macro domain interacts with ADP-ribose, suggesting further investigating the role of the macro domain in infection. the core of the structure of MERS-CoV macro domain is a seven-stranded -sheet in the order of 1-2-7-6-3-5-4. the central -sheet is sandwiched between six -helices, with 1, 2, and 3 packing onto one face and 4, 5, and 6 onto the other. in the initial refinement cycle, a strong bent electron density (continuous at 1 cutoff) was unambiguously identified as an ADP-ribose molecule. adenine moiety resides in the hydrophobic cavity containing Gly-19, Ala-21, Ile-47, Pro-123, Leu-124, and Val-152. adenine moiety resides in the hydrophobic cavity containing Gly-19, Ala-21, Ile-47, Pro-123, Leu-124, and Val-152. structure-based multiple sequence alignment showed that this aspartic acid is conserved among coV macro domains. Oxygen atoms of the pyrophosphate in ADP-ribose contact surrounding residues via hydrogen bonding with nitrogen atoms in backbone amides. the second ribose is stabilized by complex hydrogen bonding with surrounding residues and water molecules. a close-up of interactions in MERS-CoV macro domain with ADP-ribose binding. amino acids and ADP-ribose are shown as sticks with carbon in marine blue and yellow, respectively. water molecules are shown as green spheres. interactions between MERS-CoV macro domain and ADP-ribose. secondary structures of MERS-CoV macro domain are depicted on the top of the alignment with arrows for strands and cylinders for helices. identical amino acids are in white and framed in red. blue and green arrowheads on the top indicate equivalent amino acids in SARS-CoV macro domain found to abolish or decrease ADRP enzymatic activities when mutated. structural divergence lies in the 1 helices, which participates in stabilization of ADP-ribose. in the MERS-CoV macro domain, the side chain of Asp-20 contacting ADP-ribose points into the cavity that holds adenine moiety. asp-23 causes variation in side chain orientation from that for Asp-20 in the MERS-CoV macro domain. the lengths of hydrogen bonds formed by the Asp-20 side chain with Ile-22 and ADP-ribose are 2.96 and 2.82, respectively. V-229E macro domain suggests less contribution of the hydrogen bond to stabilization of ADP-ribose (41). differences in strength of the hydrogen bond and orientation of the side chain in Asp residues may result in differential binding affinities of ADP-ribose. the Tm of the macro domain from thermal transition monitored by CD was 43 °C. however, the addition of ADP-ribose significantly increased the Tm to 51 °C. the significant increase in Tm suggests the interaction between the MERS-CoV macro domain and ADP-ribose. 0.057 mm MERS-CoV macro domain containing 0.057 mm. both DSF and ITC measurements were used to examine the equilibrium dissociation constant (Kd) of ADP-ribose. the MERS-CoV macro domain interacts with ADP-ribose. this suggests further investigating the role of the macro domain in MERS-CoV infection. the core of the structure of MERS-CoV macro domain is a seven-stranded -sheet in the order of 1-2-7-6-3-5-4. the central -sheet is sandwiched between six -helices, with 1, 2, and 3 packing onto one face and 4, 5, and 6 onto the other. in the initial refinement cycle, a strong bent electron density (continuous at 1 cutoff) was unambiguously identified as an ADP-ribose molecule. adenine moiety resides in the hydrophobic cavity containing Gly-19, Ala-21, Ile-47, Pro-123, Leu-124, and Val-152. the side chain of Asp-20 contacts the N-6 atom of the pyrimidine ring in the adenine moiety via direct hydrogen bonding. this residue is critical for binding specificity of the macro domain. structure-based multiple sequence alignment showed that this aspartic acid is conserved among coV macro domains. ribose-3′′ oxygen atom forms a hydrogen bond with nitrogen atoms in backbone amides of Ile-47, Ser-126, Gly-128, and Phe-130. ribose-1′′ oxygen atom forms a hydrogen bond with the nitrogen atom in the side chain of Asn-38. a close-up of interactions in MERS-CoV macro domain with ADP-ribose binding. amino acids and ADP-ribose are shown as sticks with carbon in marine blue and yellow, respectively; oxygen in red; nitrogen in blue; and phosphorus in orange. secondary structures of MERS-CoV macro domain are depicted on the top of the alignment with arrows for strands and cylinders for helices. consensus amino acids among macro domains in CoVs with similarity score >0.7 are framed in yellow and depicted at the bottom of the alignment. structural divergence lies in the 1 helices, which participates in stabilization of ADP-ribose. in the MERS-CoV macro domain, the side chain of Asp-20 contacting ADP-ribose points into the cavity that holds adenine moiety. the lengths of hydrogen bonds formed by the Asp-20 side chain with Ile-22 and ADP-ribose are 2.96 and 2.82, respectively. the differential strength of hydrogen bonds formed by Asp with ADP-ribose may result from different residues in the 1 helix. differences in the context of hydrogen bonds formed by the conserved Asp with ADP-ribose may result in differential binding affinities for ADP-ribose. the relationship between binding affinities of ADP-ribose in macro domains and differential pathogenicity of human CoVs needs further investigation.
